entities.name: Bamital
entities.description: Bamital was a botnet active until 2013 and then taken down by Microsoft. It generated 26 domains each under 4 TLDs per day by hashing date and domain index. Symantec has a technical report.

entities.name: BeeBone
entities.description: This DGA comes with a hardcoded part to which numbers 0 to 20 are appended, followed by one of 5 TLDs (com, org, net, biz, info).

entities.name: Bobax
entities.credits: Implementation: Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann, Steffen Enders.
entities.description: Adding this DGA for the sake of completeness. Generates 231 third-level domains for DDNS provider domains: dyndns.org, yi.org, dynserv.com, mooo.com

entities.name: Blackhole
entities.description: This DGA is attributed to some campaigns of Blackhole EK and also been termed as RunForestRun. Other blogs set it in relation to Gootkit. One domain is generated per 12h, all are 16 chars long and under .ru TLD.

entities.name: Bedep
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Dennis Schwarz / Arbor](https://www.arbornetworks.com/asert/2015/04/bedeps-dga-trading-foreign-exchange-for-malware-domains/) Networks further credits to Cyphort, Zscaler, and kafeine for discovery Adapted for DGArchive: Steffen Enders
entities.description: tbd.

entities.name: Banjori
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Johanes Bader](http://www.johannesbader.ch/2015/02/the-dga-of-banjori/). Adapted for DGArchive: Steffen Enders. Additional seeds: [Kleissner & Associates](http://blog.kleissner.org/?p=192)
entities.description: Banjori is a classic banking trojan, mostly targeting countries with German language. While old variants had hardcoded URLs, versions from 2013 and on exposed DGA behaviour. The DGA varies the first 4 characters of its seed domain, generating up to 15.373 variations and uses exclusively the *.com TLD.

entities.name: CCleaner DGA
entities.credits: Implementation: Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann, found by Talos.
entities.description: DGA found in the backdoored version of CCleaner (5.33), Pattern is ab%x%x.com, 1 domain per month.

entities.name: Cryptolocker
entities.description: Cryptolocker was a ransomware that was delivered by [Gameover P2P](https://dgarchive.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/site/families.html#gameoverp2p-details). Later variants were using a DGA for reaching its C&C Servers. Per day, 1000 domains are generated. Characteristic for this DGA is a length of 12 to 15 characters for the domain name, and usage of the TLDs *.com, *.net, *.biz, *.ru, *.org, *.co.uk, *.info

entities.name: Corebot
entities.credits: As described in this [blog post](http://johannesbader.ch/2015/09/the-dga-of-corebot/) by Johannes Bader
entities.description: Generates 40-50 domains per month, using *.ddns.net and cn/com/cc/ws/sg/in as TLDs.

entities.name: Chir
entities.description: DGA as found in a simple downloader.

entities.name: Chinad
entities.description: Alphanumeric AGDs under 7 TLDs, 256 domains possible.

entities.name: Darkshell
entities.description: This DGA modifies domains based on a seed domain, by in/decrementing chars at a offset, leading to potentially invalid domains as shown below.

entities.name: Dyre
entities.description: Dyre was first identified [June 2014](http://phishme.com/project-dyre-new-rat-slurps-bank-credentials-bypasses-ssl/), and since then has become one of the major banking threats. Its DGA is a tertiary communication channel, besides its primary SSL encrypted traffic and (?) backup P2P capability. Domain generation is based on the current day, with up to 1000 domains. Domains are valid for one day, have a fixed length of 34 characters, with the first one being linearly walking through the alphabet (see below) and the remaining 33 being cut from the SHA256 resulting from date+index. The DGA uses 8 TLDs: *.cc, *.ws, *.to, *.in, *.hk, *.cn, *.tk, *.so

entities.name: DirCrypt
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Johanes Bader](http://www.johannesbader.ch/2015/03/the-dga-of-dircrypt/). Adapted for DGArchive: Steffen Enders
entities.description: As the name suggests, DirCrypt is a ransomware family, active since at least July 2013. The DGA generates 30 domains per seed and uses only the *.com domain.

entities.name: DiamondFox
entities.description: Generates n Domain per day, with a choosable start date, using 4 TLDs: *.com, *.net, *.org, *.info

entities.name: EKforward
entities.description: This DGA has been discovered on compromised Linux servers and is likely used in a proxy scheme involving exploit kits.

entities.name: Emotet.C
entities.description: Emotet is an information stealer, whose DGA variant has been first identified in [August 2014](http://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/threat/encyclopedia/entry.aspx?Name=Trojan:Win32/Emotet.C). The DGA is used as primary C&C channel, the domain generation time-based and initialized with the current date, obtained through a query to a Microsoft website. In the variant analyzed, domains were generated in 384 second intervals. A flag also shifts the seed, doubling the domains to 450 domains per day. Domains have a fixed length of 16 characters and use exclusively the *.eu domain.

entities.name: Feodo
entities.description: Three campaigns of Feodo have been observed using a DGA, which would generate 64 domains per seed. Each of the domains would have length 16-18 chars and use the .RU TLD.

entities.name: Fobber
entities.credits: Implementation: Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann, Johanes Bader.
entities.description: This is likely a fork or evolution of Tinba DGA. All generated domains have the same length and TLD.

entities.name: Gspy
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: Johannes Bader. Adapted for DGArchive: Daniel Plohmann.
entities.description: Gspy uses a hex representation of random numbers to generate its 16 char long domains.

entities.name: Gozi (Days+Monthly+Seasonal)
entities.description: Gozi uses a wordlist-based DGA, with wordlists being derived from web-accessible documents such as the US constitution, declaration of independence or RFCs. GoCERT.ch has detailed blog post on the conversion of wordlists.

entities.name: Gameover DGA
entities.description: [Gameover DGA](http://blog.malcovery.com/blog/breaking-gameover-zeus-returns?utm_campaign=Gameover+Zeus+Return) is the supposed decessor of [Gameover P2P](https://dgarchive.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/site/families.html#gameoverp2p-details), which was taken out in in June 2014 in [Operation Tovar](http://blog.shadowserver.org/2014/06/08/gameover-zeus-cryptolocker/). Gameover DGA is just as Gameover P2P a banking / information stealing botnet, but using DGA as primary means for contacting its C&C servers. At the time of writing, two sub-botnets have been identified that differ in the seed used (0x35190501, 0x52e645) and the numberof domains generated per day (1000, 10000 correspondingly). Characteristic for this DGA is that due to the algorithm about half of all generated domains start with the character '1'. The TLDs used are evenly distributed among *.com, *.net, *.biz, *.org. The average the domain length without TLD is around 26 characters.

entities.name: Infy
entities.description: Generates 20-60 domains per week, using 3 TLDs: *.space, *.net, *.top

entities.name: Locky
entities.description: The ransomware Locky was first spotted in early 2016 and has been set in [relation with Dridex](http://researchcenter.paloaltonetworks.com/2016/02/locky-new-ransomware-mimics-dridex-style-distribution/). There are two variants, however, the first one seems only having been a test while the second has been observed with many different seeds, changing on almost a daily basis. The domains of this second version use one of 14 TLDs and have a length of 5-16 chars. 8 domains are generated per two days.

entities.name: Mirai
entities.description: Mirai started using a DGA in December 2016, GoCERT.ch has detailed blog post on this DGA similar to Ranbyus. It's also covered by 360.cn

entities.name: Matsnu DGA
entities.description: Matsnu is a spam / infrastructure malware primarily used in Europe to spread other malware and proliferate its own network. Since mid 2014, it is using a DGA for reaching its C&C Servers. The DGA was changed early 2015, when seeds were changed and an optional dash was introduced. The domains are valid for 3 days, totalling to nine valid domains per day. Characteristic for this DGA is the combination of words taken from two word lists embedded in the malware and exclusive use of the *.com TLD.

entities.name: Nymaim
entities.description: Nymaim is a [heavily obfuscated](http://www.welivesecurity.com/2013/08/26/nymaim-obfuscation-chronicles/) infrastructure malware, primarily targeting Germany. It has been observed to expose [ransomware functionality](https://www.eset.com/int/about/press/articles/article/nymaim-ransomware-still-active-finding-new-infection-vector-to-spread-black-hat-seo/) as well. It uses the DGA besides hardcoded C&C domains. The DGA is based on time and will generate 30 domains per day, using *.ru, *.net, *.org, *.biz, *.info, *.com TLDs.

entities.name: Necurs
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Johanes Bader](http://www.johannesbader.ch/2015/02/the-dgas-of-necurs/). Adapted for DGArchive: Steffen Enders.
entities.description: tbd.

entities.name: Oderoor
entities.credits: As described in this [blog post](https://www.johannesbader.ch/2015/12/krakens-two-domain-generation-algorithms//) by Johannes Bader
entities.description: Similar to Bobax/Kraken but uses com/net/tv/cc or dyndns.org/com/net as TLDs and generates 100 or 200 domains.

entities.name: Omexo
entities.description: MD5-based DGA

entities.name: Proslikefan DGA
entities.description: This DGA was detailed by Johannes Bader in his blog. It generates 10 domains per TLD per day, with known TLDs being .cc, .co and .eu

entities.name: PandaBanker DGA
entities.description: DGA of PandaBanker as described in [Arbor blog](https://www.arbornetworks.com/blog/asert/panda-bankers-future-dga/). It's essentially a sha256-based DGA with fixed 2byte suffixes, including the TLD.

entities.name: PadCrypt
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Johanes Bader](https://www.johannesbader.ch/2016/03/the-dga-of-padcrypt/). Adapted for DGArchive: Daniel Plohmann.
entities.description: Yet another ransomware, using a DGA. The DGA generates 24 or 72 domains per seed and uses the following TLDs: com/co.uk/de/org/net/eu/info/online/co/cc/website.

entities.name: Qadars
entities.credits: Johannes Bader [identified](https://malwr.com/analysis/NTMxMWQxOWU4ZjlmNDhhM2I0NzU2NTEzZWE2Y2U3ZTY/), reversed, and reimplemented this DGA
entities.description: PseudoManuscrypt is a malware that steals information and provides virtually full control over the target system. It was named due to similarities to Lazarus Group's Manuscrypt malware. The DGA generates a large number of domains based on the hardcoded domains and a keyword which are not time-dependent

entities.name: QakBot
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: Thorsten Jenke, Daniel Plohmann
entities.description: tbd.

entities.name: Ranbyus
entities.description: Ranbyus generates 40 domains of length 14 (32bit) or 17 (64bit) under TLDs: in/me/cc/su/tw/net/com/pwd/org.

entities.name: Redyms
entities.description: Generates 34 domains of varying length, split by a dash, using .net TLD. Not time-dependent.

entities.name: Ramdo
entities.credits: Implementation: Blog by Microsoft and another seed submitted by an anonymous source
entities.description: Generates 1000 domains of 16 chars length, not time-dependent. Uses TLDs: org.

entities.name: Rovnix
entities.description: Rovnix makes use of hardcoded C&C URLs, a backup DGA, and third-tier backup connectivity to Tor/I2P. Per seed, it generates up to 10.000 domains under TLDs: ru/com/net/biz/cn.

entities.name: Ramnit
entities.description: amnit is a file infector first described in 2010. It has man-in-the-browser functionality similar to Zeus. In 2012, the family started using a DGA for C&C lookups. A unique seed is used to generate domains, with no limitation for the number of domains. Characteristic for this DGA is the independence from time and unlimited validity for domains, a length between 8 and 19 characters for domain names consisting of [a-y] (z is excluded by error?), and exclusive use of the *.com TLD.

entities.name: Szribi
entities.description: Szribi is one of the oldest DGAs. It uses a buggy offset table generation that reduced the domain alphabet to 'qwertyuiopasdfg'. It generates 4 domains of length 8 under *.com per 1-3 days, depending on the current day of month.

entities.name: Symmi
entities.description: Symmi has been first described in this blog post focusing on its DGA by [Johannes Bader](http://www.johannesbader.ch/2015/01/the-dga-of-symmi/). The earliest samples to have exposed similar DGA behaviour are dated mid December 2014. A whole set of parameters is used to control the algorithm: Min/max subdomain length, number of domains per time period and length of this period plus a magic to shift the date-based seed. Domain generation itself is based on two alphabets (vowels / consonants) and a well-known PRNG, the Linear Congruential Generator (LCG). For the variant described, up to 64 domains are generated per half of month; the subdomain part has a length between between 8 and 15 characters and the domains are hosted below ddns.com.

entities.name: Sphinx Zeus DGA
entities.description: DGA of Sphinx Zeus as described in [Arbor blog](https://www.arbornetworks.com/blog/asert/great-dga-sphinx/). It produces 128 domains per day with fixed length of 16 characters under .com TLD.

entities.name: Shifu
entities.credits: Found by: [X-Force](https://securityintelligence.com/shifu-masterful-new-banking-trojan-is-attacking-14-japanese-banks/). Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann
entities.description: Generates 777 domains of fixed length, a single TLD. Not time-dependent.

entities.name: Sutra TDS
entities.credits: Pointer by Kafeine, Javascript by [MalwareMustDie?](http://pastebin.com/raw/EAHfMktC), DGArchive adaption by Daniel Plohmann.
entities.description: This DGA is code-wise strongly related to Blackhole / RunForestRun. Originally also Javascript-based, and same modus operandi for seed derivation.

entities.name: Sisron
entities.credits: [Johannes Bader](https://johannesbader.ch/2016/06/the-dga-of-sisron/) reversed this DGA after I found it (thx to Shadowserver).
entities.description: Sisron produces 4 domains per day (but using a sliding window reaching 10 days back when doing lookups). For generation it uses the base64 representation of a date string.

entities.name: Simda
entities.credits: [Abuse.ch for pointing me towards this and providing samples](https://www.abuse.ch/). Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann
entities.description: Simda is a information stealing malware which is also capable of modifying websites through injects. [Microsoft](http://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/threat/encyclopedia/Entry.aspx?Name=Win32/Simda), started detailing it in 2011, first use of a DGA as primary C&C channel has been identified in 2012. The algorithm makes use a crypted set of parameters, describing how many characters a DGA domain shall have, and what TLD to use. The DGA is not based on time and will generate 1000 domains. TLDs obsered so far are: *.eu, *.info.

entities.name: Tsifiri
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: Johannes Bader, Daniel Plohmann
entities.description: This DGA generates 59 domains in total with the very recognizable pattern as shown below:

entities.name: TinyBanker DGA
entities.description: TinyBanker is an extremely compact banking malware that uses hooking to intercept and manipulate HTTP(S) requests. The name results from its small memory footprint. Since mid 2014, a new variant surfaced that is using a DGA as backup in case the primary C&C domain is unreachable. This is also one of the first consequences from the [source code leak](https://www.csis.dk/en/csis/news/4303/) in 2014 The domains are not tied to temporal validity. A set of up to 1000 ordered names is generated. The names depend on the embedded RC4 key, the initial hardcoded domain and a single hardcoded TLD suffix. Characteristic for this DGA is the independence from time for generation, a fixed length of 12 characters for domain names and exclusive used of the TLD harcoded in the binary. Dependence on the initial domain and the RC4 key means a unique DGA set for each campaign where this malware is used.

entities.name: Torpig
entities.credits: Implementation: Brett Stone-Gross, [as cited by Stefano Schiavoni](https://www.politesi.polimi.it/bitstream/10589/78505/1/2013_04_Schiavoni.pdf).
entities.description: tbd.

entities.name: Urlzone
entities.description: First spotting of Urlzone dates back as far as [2009](http://labs.m86security.com/2009/09/malware-analysis-trojan-banker-urlzonebebloh/), rendering it one of the most enduring banking bots. In August 2014, the family adopted usage of a DGA, being used to prolong the reachability of its C&C servers. A unique seed is used to generate domains, with no limitation for the number of domains. Characteristic for this DGA is the independence from time and unlimited validity for domains, a length between 14 and 19 characters for domain names consisting of [a-z] and 123945, and alternating use of the *.com and *.net TLD.

entities.name: UD4
entities.description: Unknown Family-tied DGA, fixed prefix (sn/al), 6 follow up letters, 5 TLDs.

entities.name: VolatileCedar
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Checkpoint](https://www.checkpoint.com/downloads/volatile-cedar-technical-report.pdf). Adapted for DGArchive: Steffen Enders
entities.description: tbd.

entities.name: WD
entities.description: Experimental DGA re-implementation targeting an exploit kit using a JS-based DGA. TLDs: *.pro, *.win

entities.name: XxHex DGA
entities.description: DGA of an unnamed downloader that generates domain with scheme xx., basically 4 billion domains per TLD but thankfully in predictable order.

entities.name: MadMax DGA
entities.description: According to Arbor Networks, MadMax is a targeted trojan. It produces one alphanumeric, 10 character long DGA domain per week, which is prefixed with www and suffixed with a weekly rotating TLDs selected from (com, net, info, org).

entities.name: Pushdo
entities.description: The Pushdo malware distribution system is an [old family](http://www.secureworks.com/cyber-threat-intelligence/threats/pushdo/) that is however still active and evolving. In 2013, it was [enhanced with a DGA](http://www.secureworks.com/assets/pdf-store/other/mv20.pdf) as backup when failing to connect to the hardcoded C&C servers. 1380 domains are valid every day, which is a result of a -30 to +15 days window of 30 domains per day that is being checked by the malware. Characteristic for this DGA is the comparatively long validity (45 days) for domains, a length between 9 and 12 characters for domain names and exclusive use of the *.com TLD. A later variant cuts off the domain generated by the .com variant after 8 chars and uses the .kz TLD instead. The domain generation uses 4 harcoded alphabets from which characters are chosen, which results in the first character always being one of 'bcdfghjklmnpqrstvwxz' and the second always being one of 'aeiouy'.

entities.name: SuppoBox
entities.description: SuppoBox has been first observed in Feburary 2013 and exposes information stealing behaviour. Especially, it self-propagates by scraping email addresses from infected systems and mailing itself to them, as described by Jason Geffner in this [report](https://media.blackhat.com/us-13/US-13-Geffner-End-To-End-Analysis-of-a-Domain-Generating-Algorithm-Malware-Family-WP.pdf). It uses the DGA as primary C&C channel. Variants using two different wordlists have been identified. The DGA is based on time and will generate a new domain composed of two words from the wordlist every 512 seconds. Altogether, it will cycle through a total of 32.768 domains, always using the *.net TLD.

entities.name: Virut
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [CERT.PL](https://www.cert.pl/PDF/Report_Virut_EN.pdf). Adapted for DGArchive: Daniel Plohmann
entities.description: Virut is a classic file infector that has been around since 2011 and mainly using Polish hardcoded domains along its DGA. A set of 100 domains is chosen from 100 sets that are generated daily (thus 10k domains per day). Domains are each 6 chars long under TLD .com. Character distribution is slightly skewed towards characters 'aeiouy'.

entities.name: Pykspa 2
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Johannes Bader](http://johannesbader.ch/2015/03/the-dga-of-pykspa/). Adapted for DGArchive: Daniel Plohmann.
entities.description: First version of Pykspa, using a algorithmically caused split set of fixed (4980) and bi-daily changing (20) domains.

entities.name: DNS Changer
entities.description: DNS changer uses a DGA to reach its DNS servers, signalling an infection. It is seeded with the uptime of the infected system in milliseconds. Johannes Bader analyzed the DGA in detail.

entities.name: Tofsee DGA
entities.description: This time-dependent DGA generates 20 domains per week, using the TLDs .ch and .biz. Domains are generated by dividing the seed repetitively to a sequence of characters, and then adding an additional a-j based on the domain index.

entities.name: Vawtrak
entities.description: DGA of Vawtrak, up to 150 domains with a fixed TLD per seed.

entities.name: Tempedreve TDD
entities.credits: As described in [Johannes Bader's blog](https://github.com/baderj/domain_generation_algorithms/tree/master/tempedreve). Contributed by Johannes Bader
entities.description: Generates 1 Domain per day, starting 2015-05-23, using 4 TLDs: *.com, *.net, *.org, *.info

entities.name: Tempedreve
entities.credits: As described in [Anubisnetworks](https://www.anubisnetworks.com/tempedreve-botnet-report). Contributed by Tiago Pereira, Anubisnetworks
entities.description: Generates 203 Domains, using 4 TLDs: *.com, *.net, *.org, *.info

entities.name: ModPack (Andromeda?)
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann. Found by CCIRC.
entities.description: DGA potentially related to a module of Andromeda

entities.name: Pushdo (TID version)
entities.credits: Implementation: Reversed + Implemented: Daniel Plohmann, Steffen Enders.
entities.description: Generates 6000 domains of 10 chars length, not time-dependent. Uses TLDs: com, net, org, ru, tv.

entities.name: Pykspa
entities.credits: Reversed + Implemented: [Johannes Bader](http://johannesbader.ch/2015/03/the-dga-of-pykspa/). Adapted for DGArchive: Daniel Plohmann.
entities.description: Second version of Pykspa, produces 200 real and 800 fake domains (not used as C&C).

entities.name: Vidro(TID)
entities.description: A simple LCG-based DGA as used by some downloader.

entities.name: Murofet
entities.description: Precursor (with 2 known seeds, variant B is unseeded) of GameoverP2P. It will produce 510 domains, each with two different TLDs. Valid for 1 day.

entities.name: Conficker
entities.credits: Reversed and implemented by [Tillmann Werner and Felix Leder](http://net.cs.uni-bonn.de/wg/cs/applications/containing-conficker/).
entities.description: onficker is an infamous worm that was active for a short period of time in 2008/2009. It has multiple variants of DGAs of which version A/B are integrated in DGArchive. The Honeynet project has provided a detailed analysis.

entities.name: GozNym 2nd Stage
entities.description: GozNym is the integration of the leaked gozi source code into Nymaim and uses a 2-stage DGA based on Nymaim's DGA. The second stage also features 5-11 char domains but only uses *.com. There are some greta blog posts on the DGA, e.g. by Talos. The domains included in DGArchive had to be bruteforced, which has been done by Thomas Barabosch of Fraunhofer FKIE.

entities.name: Hesperbot
entities.description: Hesperbot surfaced in [August 2013](http://www.eset.com/us/resources/white-papers/Hesperbot_Whitepaper.pdf). It is a full-blown banking trojan, coming with a mobile component, which uses a DGA as backup when failing to connect to the hardcoded C&C servers. Every campaign uses a unique seed to generate its domains, with typically below 100 generated backup domains each. Characteristic for this DGA is the independence from time and unlimited validity for domains, a length between 8 and 25 characters for domain names and exclusive use of the characters [a-z] as well as the *.com TLD.

entities.name: Gameover P2P
entities.description: [Gameover P2P](http://net.cs.uni-bonn.de/fileadmin/user_upload/plohmann/2013-MALWARE-goz.pdf) was an exceptionally robust botnet active for about 2.5 years until its takedown in [Operation Tovar](http://blog.shadowserver.org/2014/06/08/gameover-zeus-cryptolocker/) in June 2014. Its primary characteristic was the sophisticated P2P-based C&C protocol and it is said to be a further development of the file infecting Zeus variant LICAT / Murofret. It also used a [DGA as backup](https://www.abuse.ch/?p=3499). The DGA calculated 1000 domains based on time. The validity interval start was 'weeks' with respect to the day of month, thus each interval starting on the 1st, 8th, 15th, 22nd, and 29th and the domains being valid for usually 7 days if it was not the end of the month. Characteristic for this DGA the uneven usage of TLDs, with more *.com domains being generated than the others (*.ru, *.info, *.biz, *.net, *.org). The average the domain length without TLD is around 25 characters.
